tum.dss.thesis.lsframework

Class AbstractSeparationOracle

  • java.lang.Object
    • tum.dss.thesis.lsframework.AbstractSeparationOracle
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    SeparationOracleInterface
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    SeparationOracle

    public abstract class AbstractSeparationOracle
extends Object
implements SeparationOracleInterface
    Abstract separation oracle which implements all common functions among different algorithms.
    Author:
    Florian Stallmann

      • ask

        public boolean ask(Vector<FloatingPoint> wz)
        Description copied from interface: SeparationOracleInterface
        Ask oracle whether given point (valuation vector) is in polytope.

        This method will call the approximation algorithm and add new integer solutions via EllipsoidMethodData.addIntegerSolution(int[], int). It will also perform all the mapping needed to call the algorithm. To retrieve the correct cut the ellipsoid method will either call getConstraintCut or getObjectiveCut.

        Specified by:
        ask in interface SeparationOracleInterface
        Parameters:
        wz - valuation vector.
        Returns:
        true if point in polytope, false otherwise.

      • getConstraintCut

        getObjectiveCut in interface SeparationOracleInterface

      • getGammaValue

        public FloatingPoint getGammaValue()
        Description copied from interface: SeparationOracleInterface
        Gets the gamma value for the deep cut.

        Note that this method might be obsolete as the LS framework always uses the gamma value 1. However, the method has been kept to make it easy to adjust this value for future experiments. For example, using the objective value or an arbitrary value other than 1 might improve the runtime.

        Specified by:
        getGammaValue in interface SeparationOracleInterface
        Returns:
        gamma.

      • translateIntegerSolution

        protected int[] translateIntegerSolution(int[] sol,
                                         Vector<FloatingPoint> wz)
        Translates the integer solution using claim 3.2 and 3.3 to a compatible solution.

        This is necessary as the approximation algorithm might return a solution which is not in set E and therefore it cannot be used for the decomposition. Additionally we need to reverse the changes we did during monotonization. See claim 3.2 and especially the second part of the proof of claim 3.3 for details.

        Parameters:
        sol - integer solution of separation oracle.
        wz - current center.
        Returns:
        translated integer solution xl added to found solutions.

      • lastWzWasAskedBefore

        public boolean lastWzWasAskedBefore()
        Description copied from interface: SeparationOracleInterface
        This method returns true if the vector of wz that was used for the last call of the ask method was already asked before.
        Specified by:
        lastWzWasAskedBefore in interface SeparationOracleInterface
        Returns:
        true if wz is a duplicate, otherwise false.

      • lastWzWasNewSolution

        public boolean lastWzWasNewSolution()
        Description copied from interface: SeparationOracleInterface
        This method returns true if the vector wz that was used for the last call of the ask method lead to a new integer solution.
        Specified by:
        lastWzWasNewSolution in interface SeparationOracleInterface
        Returns:
        true if new solution was found and it is not a duplicate, otherwise false.

      • setObjectiveAsGamma

        public void setObjectiveAsGamma(boolean deep_gamma)
        Description copied from interface: SeparationOracleInterface
        Sets if the objective value should be used as gamma value for the deep cut.
        Specified by:
        setObjectiveAsGamma in interface SeparationOracleInterface
        Parameters:
        deep_gamma - true if objective value should be used as gamma.
